title: 112_hr6574
content: The Act may be cited as the "Servicemember Mental Health Review Act". Since September 11, 2001, around 30,000 veterans have been discharged from the Armed Forces due to personality or adjustment disorders. These veterans are then restricted from accessing various disability benefits and often struggle to find employment due to the label on their discharge paperwork. The Department of Defense's compliance in separating members based on these disorders has been questioned by the Government Accountability Office. The Government Accountability Office found low regulatory compliance in separating veterans based on personality or adjustment disorders from 2001 to 2007. A Mental Health Discharge Board of Review is needed to ensure wrongly separated veterans can access disability benefits and employment opportunities. The Department of Defense will review military separations based on mental conditions that do not amount to disability. The Department of Defense will establish Mental Health Discharge Boards of Review to review separations based on mental conditions not amounting to disability. Each board will consist of at least five members, including a licensed psychologist and psychiatrist. The `Mental Health Discharge Board of Review' will consist of at least five members, including a licensed psychologist and psychiatrist. The board will be equipped with administrative and behavioral health support staff. Covered individuals are members and former members of the armed forces separated due to mental conditions not amounting to disability since September 11, 2001. Covered individuals are members and former members of the armed forces separated since September 11, 2001, due to mental conditions not amounting to disability. The Secretary of Defense must ensure that each covered individual is notified of their right to a review by the Mental Health Discharge Board of Review. The military department responsible for the covered individual's service before separation must provide this notification. The Secretary of Defense must ensure that covered individuals are notified of their right to a review by the Mental Health Discharge Board of Review. The military department responsible for the individual's service before separation must provide this notification. If the individual does not receive the notification, they or their representative can request a review by the Board. Legal counsel is required for the notification process. The covered individual or their representative can request a review by the Mental Health Discharge Board of Review for separation from the armed forces. Legal counsel is required for this process, including the right to obtain private counsel or access organizations that provide counsel at no cost. The Board will review the findings of the Department of Defense psychologist or psychiatrist regarding the mental condition and the decisions leading to separation. The Mental Health Discharge Board of Review will review the findings of the Department of Defense psychologist or psychiatrist, the separation decisions, and the adherence to separation processes for covered individuals. The review will be based on records from the Department of Defense and Veterans Affairs, along with any additional evidence presented to the Board. The Mental Health Discharge Board of Review will base its review on records from the Department of Defense and Veterans Affairs, along with any additional evidence presented. The board will consider all evidence, including private mental health records submitted by the covered individual. If the board proposes a review on its own, consent must be obtained from the covered individual or their representative before proceeding. The Mental Health Discharge Board of Review requires consent from the covered individual or their representative before conducting a review. After completing the review, the board must provide a statement of reasons for their decision. The covered individual can request a reconsideration if new evidence is presented. The board may make recommendations based on their findings. The Mental Health Discharge Board of Review may recommend different actions regarding a covered individual, such as no negative recharacterization of separation, retirement for disability, or recharacterization of separation. The individual can request a reconsideration with new evidence. The Mental Health Discharge Board of Review can recommend actions for a covered individual, including no negative recharacterization of separation, retirement for disability, or recharacterization of separation to various categories. This may also involve issuing a new disability rating for the individual. The Mental Health Discharge Board of Review can recommend actions for a covered individual, including issuing a new disability rating or correcting military records based on their recommendations. If retirement for disability is not recommended, a brief statement of reasons must be provided to the individual or their representative. The Mental Health Discharge Board of Review can recommend corrections to military records for covered individuals. The Secretary of the military department will implement these corrections, effective from the date of separation. If a covered individual received a lump-sum payment at separation, their future benefits will be adjusted accordingly. The Secretary of the military department will adjust future benefits for covered individuals who received a lump-sum payment at separation. Regulations for this section will be prescribed by the Secretary of Defense. Implementation of Mental Health Discharge Boards of Review required under section 1554b of title 10, United States Code, must be completed within 90 days of the enactment of this Act by the Secretary of Defense. Regulations for this section will also be prescribed by the Secretary of Defense.
